Brief Description: Has most of the recent Census data; fairly easy to make custom tables

The National Historical Geographic Information System (NHGIS) provides easy access to summary tables and time series of population, housing, agriculture, and economic data, along with GIS-compatible boundary files, for years from 1790 through the present and for all levels of U.S. census geography, including states, counties, tracts, and blocks.

Short for Federal Reserve Economic Data, FRED is an online database consisting of hundreds of thousands of economic data time series from scores of national, international, public, and private sources. FRED, created and maintained by the Research Department at the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, goes far beyond simply providing data: It combines data with a powerful mix of tools that help the user understand, interact with, display, and disseminate the data.
This tool allows you to see annual migration between Alaska's boroughs and census areas based on permanent fund dividend filings.
Allows you to select a place or borough/census area and see a graph and table of the estimated population from 2010 to the current year.
Allows you to select from a number of geographies and see selected 2020 Census tables for that area.
Allows you to type in a geography and then displays a PDF map.

Notes:
I am not really clear on the scope of your interest. As far as tools we use the usual suspects SPSS, SAS, Stata, R, Excel. When required we use Python. We regularly use Public Health's data for vital statistics at the individual level and are required to sign security agreements to use it. These are central to the detailed population projections to 2050 we update annually. The same can be said for hospital discharge data. We do long term enrollment projections for all the school districts and have access to student files for modelling purposes with restrictions and compliance with FERPA. We also assist the school districts with school attendance zone mapping working with the boards and with full access to the property records held by our three counties. That data also assists in annually determining the current property values within each district which are not regularly updated. Those data are  
also used when estimating the economic impact of the remediation of brownfields over time and also for general economic development evaluation of state "investments". We gain access to the state's accident data when we are looking at pedestrian and bicyclist involvement. The same can be said when investigating issues of substance abuse or evaluating the success or failure of programs dealing with teen drivers.we fairly regularly evaluate bluetooth data collected by DelDOT, the transportation agency and we use DelDOL Department of Labor as a source for locations and employment of workers. We also do original data collection for DelDOT on Origin and Destinations of trips by drivers for a variety of purposes. Along with these State/County purposes we regularly use the Current Population Survey, the American Community Survey, the BRFSS surveys conducted annually by most states for CDC, and the Census Data Center which provides detailed information on-line. Hope this helps a bit. Ed

Data Tools/Application Name: enrollment projections for all the school districts

Brief Description: The DC Office of Planning (OP) Demographic Data Hub presents selected demographic, social, housing and economic data and analysis to help guide decisionmaking. The information is presented in geographic profiles, policy, interactive and downloadable maps, open data search, reports, studies and other downloadable resources that users can incorporate into their research and data products. The Hub was built by the DC State Data Center in collaboration with the Environmental Systems Research Institute (Esri), the DC Office of the Chief Technology Officer (OCTO) and uses many features of the ArcGIS platform and solution templates

The Data Dashboard provides a detailed look at key indicators of upward mobility in Washington, DC. They highlight outcomes across racial and ethnic groups as well as across communities. The dashboard equips leaders, impacted residents, community organizations, researchers, and advocates with the information they need to better understand current inequities and design more effective approaches to advance upward mobility. The dashboard includes data for the DC Upward Mobility Project’s three policy areas— housing, financial wellbeing, and workforce development/adult education. The DC State Data Center assisted in building this dashboard and is responsible for management and annual updates.

Notes:
I’ve attached the primary resources that I use in the following:
·        Kansas Statistical Abstract (https://ipsr.ku.edu/ksdata/ksah/).  The KSA is an annual compendium of data for Kansas communities.  Organized into seventeen chapters it gives communities free, easy access to key demographic, housing, socio-economic data.
·        Kansas Data Archive (https://ipsr.ku.edu/ksdata/#ksa).  Interactive tool to create tables, graphs, and maps from database with time-series of county and state level (Kansas) data.
·        Kansas Regional Data Portal (https://ipsr.ku.edu/sdc/region.php).  Application designed with and for our Economic Development Districts to assist them in completing their Comprehensive Economic Development Strategy (CEDS) reports.
I use a variety of state sources, but our state lacks data tools.  Most state agencies publish data only in PDF which requires some effort to liberate and make usable for local governments.  I hope this helps!  Please let me know if you have any questions.
Xan
